chunk_summary: Severe or complicated inpatient enteric fever treatment involves parenteral antibiotics, supportive care, and tailored regimens based on clinical response, susceptibility, and complications like intestinal perforation or shock.
learning_objectives: Understand the first-line and alternative antibiotic regimens for severe enteric fever in hospitalized children.
Recognize the role of adjunct therapies, including corticosteroids, in managing complications like shock or encephalopathy.
Identify supportive care measures and the importance of monitoring for complications such as intestinal perforation or organ dysfunction.
key_facts: Ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day (max 4 g/day) IV for 10–14 days is a common first-line treatment.
Cefotaxime 150–200 mg/kg/day in 3–4 divided doses is an alternative when ceftriaxone is unsuitable.
Azithromycin 20 mg/kg/day (oral or IV) may be added for suspected reduced cephalosporin susceptibility.
Dexamethasone 3 mg/kg loading dose, followed by 1 mg/kg every 6 hours for 48 hours, is reserved for shock or encephalopathy.
Broaden antibiotics to cover secondary intra-abdominal flora if intestinal perforation is suspected.
reference_quote: A common first-line regimen for severe disease is ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day (maximum 4 g/day) given intravenously once daily or in divided doses for 10–14 days, tailored to clinical response and susceptibility results.
